I've just started the third volume of #1Q84, and if I had to come up with one sentence to describe everything that's happened so far, it would be that the only constant in life is change.
I've been reading 1Q84 by Haruki Murakami for a looong time, but I've enjoyed every bit of it. 'The words sing on the page.' I've never found a novel so suited to the phrase.

I would call that a success for Disney's public relations department.

It's interesting how differently reporters pronounce Disney's name as opposed to Fox, Netflix, Amazon or others. The others are pronounced with grim matter-of-fact tones. The word Disney is spoken the way someone would talk about Santa to a child.

RT @ItsDaniCarr: -taps microphone- Severus Snape was a horrible person. -alarms go off- AND even though he MAY have done some good thing…

Fifth and Final: I honestly believe that problems like Donald Trump and Kim Jong-un would go away if someone made them sit down and watch SAO. Once they see Kirito and Asuna, all their hatred would fade away. (If needs be, Harry Potter would be a satisfactory substitute)

Question the Fourth: Honest plea to the world of Twitter - can anyone recommend an anime/manga/light novel that does not include female sex robots? (not literal robots of course, I just mean characters that many Japanese writers think can pass for women)

Third Thought: Diehard anime fans can scream at me all they want, but I fucking love Sword Art Online ❤️ Like, I know it has one or two questionable moments (cough), but who can deny the glory that is Kirito and Asuna? That's right, no one.

Second thing: WHY must so many anime and manga series sexualise women?? This is probably my number one pet peeve. Like, the story is so so good, and then out of nowhere - OOPS, all the women are naked for no reason.
First question/thought: Why is anime so addictive? What makes those artists in Japan so good at reeling audiences in? I want to know their secret,
I am such a Geek and I am Proud of This fact (name of thread).

I just can't imagine why Xi Jinping would be considered less influential than Donald Trump. This is the year when Trump has forced isolationism on the US, while China has become the world's largest and most influential economy.
Honest question: does Time magazine primarily consider people who concern America for its person of the year? Or does it give equal attention to international figures?

Trump now looks to be actively trying to start World War III. First he antagonised North Korea - now he wants to enrage the entire Muslim world by giving Jerusalem to Israel. It was nice knowing everyone.
